Q19: I think that revision map was INCREDIBLY confusing. If more clear it would have been more helpful. Also, I feel like the revision feedback told me the types of revisions that I made, but not which I NEEDED to make. So it is very likely that I had the same errors in every draft..

Q19:
1. Functional: it would be helpful if two buttons "Go to previous sentence" and "Go to next sentence" are added when the user is comparing sentences.
2. I found it happens often that I actually reordered the structure (e.g. phases or sub-sentences ) of one sentence but the system failed to detect this change and thought it was just a fluency change.
3. The colors are not very clear, as some of them are very similar to each other. Also texts highlighted by many colors are hard to read.
Q20:
1. I should make more content changes.
2. I should make my texts more concise.

Q19: More specific highlighting, especially when there are multiple highlights in one sentence. Splitting deleted and added content into different catagories rather than sharing the same ones could be less confusing.
Q20: Suggestions that I should try to add more content  pertaining to warm colors rather than small edits.

Q19: It's not as clear as it could be how to switch between reviewing changes and revising essays. There also is no indication, when reviewing multiple inter-sentential changes, which change you're currently evaluating; simple a black outline on the one most recently clicked-on would be an huge help. The saving/submitting UX is also not integrated well into the system; I know this is an internal prototype, but for distribution, browser alerts are probably not the way to go.
Q20: I tried, much more intentionally, to make substance-level changes (adding evidence, supporting my reasoning, etc.) rather than adjust my wording, tone, and sentence structure.

Q19: The system could be more helpful in the sense that it could provide more of actual revision advice for further editing rather than just pointing out the differences in the first two drafts. Additionally, the system could also point out whether the revisions I made in draft 2 helped improve the quality of writing after going through draft 1.
Q20: My decision to make revisions to Draft 3 was mainly caused by looking at what the system had highlighted in terms of the changes from draft 1 to draft 2. I looked more closely at these sections to pinpoint any other changes I could make to improve the quality of the paper.

Q19: I can't think of anything specific, but I did think the mechanisms for marking revision purposes as correct or incorrect was the most clunky and unintuitive part of the system.
Q20: I believe that most people are encouraged to participate in a task when it has become "gamified." That is to say, the charts made me want to get a higher "score" on my revisions. With the revisions made into a chart, I wanted more of the chart to include more important revisions. I'm not sure I succeeded, but I think I could with repeated uses.

Q19:
The system could be more helpful by perhaps:
- noting/highlighting the main ideas of each paragraph, making the writer aware of what each paragraph focuses on/what unnecessary details to omit
- improving accuracy by taking into account the formatting some writers stick to (for example: some ease in/out of paragraphs by having an intro/conclusion -- some of the highlighted revision didn't identify these correctly)
- for weaker writers it could offer stronger words to help improve overall strength of piece
Q20: I took into account the revisions I made in draft 1, 2 and how each added to my essay based on what the system identified them as. Also, I think that seeing these colors (warm/cool) all over one's drafts will push them to examine their next draft more closely for errors. The flashes of color causes the writer to have a more focused view of the topic at hand.

Q19: If it was feasible, it could be more helpful by analyzing revisions written in real-time so you get immediate feedback on your writing, rather then getting feedback at the end of the revision process.
